setup.question: What is not clearly an element of injustice in this story?

Text.text: Classism is not here, this is a story about sexism:
(some words omitted to save quote space)
There are definitive mentions of classism in this story. The story centers on the fact that
, implying there are hierarchical groups in society.
.. he goes on to name more classes of ranked officers, groups which stand in a higher position than
, as the Kirks identify. There is an issue of supply in this story, given that Lil Kirk asks
and Kirk responds
- the captains don't prioritize the Kirks in the distribution of life saving resources. Rampant classism.

Both are plausible, but I think B's descriptions aren't super closely supported by their quotes. e.g. "Secret to his people's enemies" doesn't imply hierarchy, just groups. 

"dying cast-aways of the void" is maybe the most convincing part of B, along with "aren't enough heat-stones to go around", but I feel like both need to be put in more context. 

A, can you put your quote in more context too, to show that sexism was being demonstrated?

Same for you B, I feel like I need to see the quotes in a bit more context to know that they imply classism.

Sure thing.
There is rampant sexism stuff in this story,

Here's context for the "you women know so much bit", 

The only mention of classes is just some minor stuff about rankings and feeling cold but these are not key to the story in the slightest.
Kirk says

- Kirk says he would like to kill the Captain's daughter to beat the allegations that he would save her because she is pretty - A quotes this part. More evidence for classism is shown through the structure of society, given that the
- they have correspondingly greater wealth when rankings and status are obtained.
. There is a pattern of oppression on the part of the Captain, inflicted upon Kirk and his family because they have lower status that the Captain.

Hmmmm now I'm torn - the quote about the huts of the engineers being bigger, and the "they think they can go on doing it" seem suggestive of classism. However, B you didn't actually respond to my request for more context....

A, can you *demonstrate* or say *why* the stuff about rankings isn't relevant?

Also yeah for both you of, if you're ignoring something I ask or the other debater says, please give a brief note about *why* you're not responding.

The rankings stuff isn't relevant because its not a question of class from a wealth perspective. B is including wealth stuff that just isn't in the story - just because B uses wealth does not mean its in the story. These are rankings but they aren't economically tied.

The sexism stuff is objectively true - B's context about how he'd kill the daughter is beating true allegations. He also doesn't kill the daughter anyway which proves it was sexism after all and he was just utilizing words to beat those obvious allegations.  
Story has always been about

who killed out of sexism. 

Additionally all the male characters recieve a lot more respect -

A is beating the phrase 'beating the allegations' to death. 
There 'respect' angle is totally out of context - Kirk is asked to rest because he is so angry, yelling
. Slander towards the captain is unheard of, and the officers threaten Kirk, telling him
but Kirk continues, questioning what the
. He says he saw
, but before he is able to expose the classism, men
. They can't even speak out against the Captains without being disciplined or punished.
These extra quotes from B are *extremely* convincing - seems super classism-based. Will end on next turn unless those quotes are super out of context or I'm missing something big

Sexism is 100% an element of injustice in this story: B never responded to the point I made last speech about the plot of the story at the top - "the death of the girl" line.
Also the classist elements of the story that B produces might be true in a vacuum but they pale in comparison to the obvious sexism I already well established.

I mean this line was alr quoted but Ill put it back here for reconsideration:

.
Seems very obvious how self-centered, mysognistic and vile Kirk is. Him having hungry sisters does not change the fact that he contributes to major rampant sexism.

A's just quoting any mention of a woman in the story. While I don't doubt these characters are misogynistic, you cannot refute the classism that exists that causes the main character to literally be dragged away in an effort to silence him about speaking out about
in regard to their hoarding of
which leave the lower classes in awful condition.
More quoting from the confrontation in which it becomes clear that there are distinct classes in this society, the upper of which step on the lower to stay alive.
Lots of evidence towards B, but there's enough evidence for A that I can't be 99% certain.
no opinion.
Seems like gender plays a role here. The kill the daughter quote is missing a word, could be out of context.
The additional context helps A. I still want more info.

I'm going to go with A because money never comes up. Captain presumably makes more money but authority and rank are distinct from class. The gender of his daughter and the animosity towards her makes me lean towards sexism.

answers.reason for outcome: Class is never mentioned, only rank and gender.

answers.judge strategies: I asked them to see some quotes in more context, and that if they are ignoring something specific to say *why* they are ignoring it.
answers.reason for outcome: I got the right answer because over time, there turned out to be more and more evidence in favor of B.
I won because I presented the details of the story in a compelling way.
